title: Barracuda girls shine at Matilda half - time mini match | Manning River Times
body_text:
Members of the Hallidays Point Sports Club enjoyed the thrill of a lifetime when they took part in a football mini-match during the half-time break of an international football fixture.

A group of 10 Barracuda girls travelled to Newcastle's McDonald Jones Stadium for the international friendly between the Matildas and Korea Republic on the night of Monday, April 7.
The group took to the field at half-time for a high-spirited game in front of a crowd of more than 28,000 spectators.
The appearance came about after Football Mid North Coast were approached by Football Australia to nominate clubs from within the area that would benefit from the opportunity and had shown the values of community football.
Barracuda's Under 8 coach, Toby Gollan said the club was grateful for the chance for their young players to have the experience of playing on the same pitch as their heroes,
"It was a lovely evening and a really special opportunity for them. One of those things that only comes around very rarely and we're very lucky that Football Mid North Coast put our club through to have that opportunity," he said.
Grassroots fortball is where the foundation starts
- Barracudas U/8 coach, Toby Gollan
You go, girl!
The participation of women and girls in football is currently in a phase of rapid expansion, with the growth of the sport's popularity among females unsurprisingly attributed to the success of the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup and the success of the Australian team at that event.
Football Australia's 2024 National Participation Report confirms football's position as Australia's most popular and fastest-growing sport, with over 1.9 million participants nationwide - an 11 per cent increase compared to 2023.
Of particular note, women and girls' participation registered an increase of 16 per cent to 221,436 participants.
With the Matildas emerging from relative obscurity in previous decades to become one of the most iconic sporting brands in the country, it is little wonder that girls are taking up the sport in greater numbers than ever.
As more girls become interested in the sport, clubs like Hallidays Point Sports Club are doing their bit to create an environment encouraging female participation.
"The growth in women in football to the Matildas and their success...the development in grassroots women and girls playing in football is huge as a result of that," Mr Gollan said.
"I know my daughter changed from playing netball to football because we took her down to a couple of World Cup matches - she was just awestruck by the size of the crowd and the excitement.
"There's an aim to foster a better environment for women in sport and promote teams of women's football and encourage more gala days, training and activities, and that sort of stuff as well."
